channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Author Correction: Global hotspots of salt marsh change and carbon emissions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06666-5

Author Correction: Global hotspots of salt marsh change and carbon emissions
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Global hotspots of salt marsh change and carbon emissions
item.dc:creator: Anthony D. Campbell
Lola Fatoyinbo
Liza Goldberg
David Lagomasino

item.title: My quest for hidden treasures in Sri Lanka’s flora
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03164-6

Sri Lankan taxonomist Bhathiya Gopallawa tapped into a network of early-career researchers to unearth a botanic gem in the tropical forest undergrowth.
item.dc:title: My quest for hidden treasures in Sri Lanka’s flora
item.dc:creator: Manasee Weerathunga

item.title: Why women earn less than men: Nobel for economic historian who probed pay gap
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03190-4

Claudia Goldin mined 200 years of data to show that greater economic growth did not lead to wage parity, nor to more women in the workplace.
item.dc:title: Why women earn less than men: Nobel for economic historian who probed pay gap
item.dc:creator: Philip Ball

item.title: Back from the brink: postdoc career optimism on the rise
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03163-7

Nature’s global survey finds that postdoctoral researchers still feel as though they are academia’s drudge labourers, but have more confidence about job prospects in a post-pandemic world.
item.dc:title: Back from the brink: postdoc career optimism on the rise
item.dc:creator: Linda Nordling

item.title: Extreme heat harms health — what is the human body’s limit?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02482-z

As deadly heatwaves become more common, researchers are studying what people can tolerate.
item.dc:title: Extreme heat harms health — what is the human body’s limit?
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: 3D printing tackles tricky materials with help from tiny crystals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03037-y

Technique that uses a molecular ‘glue’ allows 3D printing to make objects from challenging materials such as semiconductors.
item.dc:title: 3D printing tackles tricky materials with help from tiny crystals

item.title: ‘Immense relief’: Universe-mapping Euclid telescope fixes problem that threatened mission
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03174-4

The European Space Agency says a software patch restored stability to its new cosmic mapper — but slower operations could extend the mission.
item.dc:title: ‘Immense relief’: Universe-mapping Euclid telescope fixes problem that threatened mission
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Gene therapies for rare diseases are under threat. Scientists hope to save them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03109-z

As industry steps aside, scientists seek innovative ways to make sure expensive treatments can reach people who need them.
item.dc:title: Gene therapies for rare diseases are under threat. Scientists hope to save them
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: M. S. Swaminathan (1925–2023), leader of India’s ‘green revolution’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03175-3

Agricultural scientist who introduced crops to end famine in India in the 1960s.
item.dc:title: M. S. Swaminathan (1925–2023), leader of India’s ‘green revolution’
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: US science agencies on track to hit 25-year funding low
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03135-x

Despite last year’s CHIPS and Science Act, which was meant to boost innovation, report predicts that Congress will cut spending on science.
item.dc:title: US science agencies on track to hit 25-year funding low
item.dc:creator: Jeff Tollefson

item.title: How to craft a research project with non-academic collaborators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03140-0

If you’re working with indigeneous researchers, citizen scientists or local communities, find out about their expectations, including ones around payment and authorship.
item.dc:title: How to craft a research project with non-academic collaborators
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: W. Jason Morgan, discoverer of plate tectonics (1935–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03145-9

Geophysicist who showed how segments of Earth’s crust move.
item.dc:title: W. Jason Morgan, discoverer of plate tectonics (1935–2023)
item.dc:creator: Lawrence M. Cathles

item.title: Your brain finds it easy to size up four objects but not five — here’s why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03136-w

Neuron activity shows that the brain uses different systems for counting up to four, and for five or more.
item.dc:title: Your brain finds it easy to size up four objects but not five — here’s why
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Author Correction: Synthesis of portimines reveals the basis of their anti-cancer activity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06699-w

Author Correction: Synthesis of portimines reveals the basis of their anti-cancer activity
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Synthesis of portimines reveals the basis of their anti-cancer activity

item.title: How carrots became orange: genomics get at the root of the matter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03035-0

The vegetable was domesticated roughly 1,200 years ago but was yellow or purple for centuries.
item.dc:title: How carrots became orange: genomics get at the root of the matter

item.title: New kind of quantum computer made using high-resolution microscope
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03141-z

Individual atoms on a surface do their first basic calculation.
item.dc:title: New kind of quantum computer made using high-resolution microscope
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: ‘In case I die, I need to publish this paper’: scientist who left the lab to fight in Ukraine
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03044-z

Neuroscientist Sergiy Sylantyev tells Nature that science and war cannot be separated.
item.dc:title: ‘In case I die, I need to publish this paper’: scientist who left the lab to fight in Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: South Korean scientists’ outcry over planned R&D budget cuts
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02841-w

In a nation with historically high levels of spending on research and development, the proposed cuts have provoked a strong response.
item.dc:title: South Korean scientists’ outcry over planned R&D budget cuts
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: An extra-erythrocyte role of haemoglobin body in chondrocyte hypoxia adaption
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06611-6

Haemoglobin produced by chondrocytes forms eosin-positive haemoglobin bodies in their cytoplasm, and deletion of these bodies causes severe hypoxia.
item.dc:title: An extra-erythrocyte role of haemoglobin body in chondrocyte hypoxia adaption

item.title: Global evidence of rapid urban growth in flood zones since 1985
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06468-9

Analysis of high-resolution annual data shows that global human settlements have expanded continuously and rapidly into flood zones, with those in the most hazardous zones increasing by 122% from 1985 to 2015.
item.dc:title: Global evidence of rapid urban growth in flood zones since 1985
item.dc:creator: Jun Rentschler
Paolo Avner
Mattia Marconcini
Rui Su
Emanuele Strano
Michalis Vousdoukas
Stéphane Hallegatte

item.title: Rock organic carbon oxidation CO<sub>2</sub> release offsets silicate weathering sink
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06581-9

Silicate weathering of uplifted rock depletes atmospheric CO2, but oxidation of revealed rock organic carbon supplies CO2, offsetting depletion to a degree dependent on regional geological history.
item.dc:title: Rock organic carbon oxidation CO<sub>2</sub> release offsets silicate weathering sink
item.dc:creator: Jesse R. Zondervan
Robert G. Hilton
Mathieu Dellinger
Fiona J. Clubb
Tobias Roylands
Mateja Ogrič

item.title: Assembly theory explains and quantifies selection and evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06600-9

Assembly theory conceptualizes objects as entities defined by their possible formation histories, allowing a unified language for describing selection, evolution and the generation of novelty.
item.dc:title: Assembly theory explains and quantifies selection and evolution
item.dc:creator: Abhishek Sharma
Dániel Czégel
Michael Lachmann
Christopher P. Kempes
Sara I. Walker
Leroy Cronin

item.title: Large-scale plasma proteomics comparisons through genetics and disease associations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06563-x

Comparisons of phenotypic and genetic association with protein levels from Icelandic and UK Biobank cohorts show that using multiple analysis platforms and stratifying populations by ancestry improves the detection of associations and allows the refinement of their location within the genome.
item.dc:title: Large-scale plasma proteomics comparisons through genetics and disease associations

item.title: A continuous fish fossil record reveals key insights into adaptive radiation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06603-6

This study presents a continuous fossil record, extracted from a series of sediment cores, that shows how haplochromine cichlids came to dominate the fish fauna of Lake Victoria in Africa.
item.dc:title: A continuous fish fossil record reveals key insights into adaptive radiation

item.title: The PTPN2/PTPN1 inhibitor ABBV-CLS-484 unleashes potent anti-tumour immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06575-7

An orally bioavailable small-molecule active-site inhibitor of the phosphatases PTPN2 and PTPN1, ABBV-CLS-484, demonstrates immunotherapeutic efficacy in mouse models of cancer resistant to PD-1 blockade.
item.dc:title: The PTPN2/PTPN1 inhibitor ABBV-CLS-484 unleashes potent anti-tumour immunity

item.title: The status of the human gene catalogue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06490-x

Although the catalogue of human protein-coding genes is nearing completion, the number of non-coding RNA genes remains highly uncertain, and for all genes much work remains to be done to understand their functions.
item.dc:title: The status of the human gene catalogue

item.title: Rare variant associations with plasma protein levels in the UK Biobank
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06547-x

A set of three papers in Nature reports a new proteomics resource from the UK Biobank and initial analysis of common and rare genetic variant associations with plasma protein levels.
item.dc:title: Rare variant associations with plasma protein levels in the UK Biobank

item.title: Sialoglycan binding triggers spike opening in a human coronavirus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06599-z

Binding of a sialoglycan-based primary receptor by the spike protein of the common cold human coronavirus HKU1 triggers conformational changes to a state that would allow binding to a second receptor required for cell entry.
item.dc:title: Sialoglycan binding triggers spike opening in a human coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Matti F. Pronker

Daniel L. Hurdiss

item.title: Bridging two insect flight modes in evolution, physiology and robophysics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06606-3

Asynchronous flight in all major groups of insects likely arose from a single common ancestor with reversions to a synchronous flight mode enabled by shifts back and forth between different regimes in the same set of dynamic parameters.
item.dc:title: Bridging two insect flight modes in evolution, physiology and robophysics
item.dc:creator: Jeff Gau
James Lynch
Brett Aiello
Ethan Wold
Nick Gravish
Simon Sponberg

item.title: Ongoing declines for the world’s amphibians in the face of emerging threats
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06578-4

The second Global Amphibian Assessment finds that the status of amphibians is continuing to deteriorate globally, driven predominantly by climate change, disease and habitat loss.
item.dc:title: Ongoing declines for the world’s amphibians in the face of emerging threats

item.title: Stringent test of QED with hydrogen-like tin
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06453-2

A high-precision, high-field test of quantum electrodynamics measuring the bound-electron g factor in hydrogen-like tin is described, which—together with state-of-the-art theory calculations—yields a stringent test in the strong-field regime.
item.dc:title: Stringent test of QED with hydrogen-like tin
item.dc:creator: J. Morgner
B. Tu
C. M. König

J. R. Crespo López-Urrutia
C. H. Keitel
S. Sturm
K. Blaum

item.title: Universality in long-distance geometry and quantum complexity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06460-3

Many different homogeneous metrics on Lie groups, which may have markedly different short-distance properties, are shown to exhibit nearly identical distance functions at long distances, suggesting a large universality class of definitions of quantum complexity.
item.dc:title: Universality in long-distance geometry and quantum complexity
item.dc:creator: Adam R. Brown
Michael H. Freedman
Henry W. Lin
Leonard Susskind

item.title: Plasma proteomic associations with genetics and health in the UK Biobank
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06592-6

The Pharma Proteomics Project generates the largest open-access plasma proteomics dataset to date, offering insights into trans protein quantitative trait loci across multiple biological domains, and highlighting genetic influences on ligand–receptor interactions and pathway perturbations across a diverse collection of cytokines and complement networks.
item.dc:title: Plasma proteomic associations with genetics and health in the UK Biobank

item.title: Scratch record
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03068-5

It’s only rock ’n’ roll.
item.dc:title: Scratch record
item.dc:creator: Steven Berger

item.title: Climate change and habitat loss push amphibians closer to extinction
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02785-1

Amphibians are the most vulnerable vertebrates worldwide, with 41% of species threatened with extinction. Habitat loss is the most common threat, and climate change is the main driver of increased extinction risk. Investment in amphibian conservation must be scaled up drastically and urgently to prevent further extinctions and reverse declines.
item.dc:title: Climate change and habitat loss push amphibians closer to extinction

item.title: Cichlid fish seized an ecological opportunity to diversify
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03014-5

The analysis of fossils in sediment cores from Lake Victoria, Africa, reveals that a group of cichlid fish rapidly diversified as the lake got larger and provided new ecological niches, whereas the other fish there did not diversify.
item.dc:title: Cichlid fish seized an ecological opportunity to diversify
item.dc:creator: Martin J. Genner

item.title: How purposeless physics underlies purposeful life
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03061-y

Evolution by natural selection peerlessly describes how life’s complexity develops — but can it be explained in terms of physics? A new approach suggests it can.
item.dc:title: How purposeless physics underlies purposeful life
item.dc:creator: George F. R. Ellis

item.title: Embracing the command line: my unexpected career in computational biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03120-4

A crash course in bioinformatics put Ming Tommy Tang on a different path.
item.dc:title: Embracing the command line: my unexpected career in computational biology
item.dc:creator: Ming Tommy Tang

item.title: Testing the limits of the standard model of particle physics with a heavy, highly charged ion
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02620-7

Quantum electrodynamics, the archetypical theory of electromagnetic interactions, describes the behaviour of charged particles and photons using quantum field theory. Measuring the g factor of a bound electron in a hydrogen-like tin ion (118Sn49+) provides one of the most stringent tests so far of quantum electrodynamics in strong electric fields.
item.dc:title: Testing the limits of the standard model of particle physics with a heavy, highly charged ion

item.title: Flood-prone areas are hotspots for urban development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03128-w

The settlement trend has continued, even as awareness of the risks of climate change has increased.
item.dc:title: Flood-prone areas are hotspots for urban development
item.dc:creator: Xiaoying You

item.title: Tiny ‘quantum dot’ particles win chemistry Nobel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03048-9

Moungi Bawendi, Louis Brus and Alexei Ekimov receive the prize for their work on glowing nanoparticles that are used in fields from electronics to surgery.
item.dc:title: Tiny ‘quantum dot’ particles win chemistry Nobel
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson
Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: How to spice up your bioinformatics skill set with AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03067-6

Incorporating machine-learning tools into data analysis can accelerate discovery and free up valuable time.
item.dc:title: How to spice up your bioinformatics skill set with AI
item.dc:creator: Rachael Pells

item.title: The disinformation sleuths: a key role for scientists in impending elections
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03102-6

Researchers in Europe have a golden opportunity to help defend democratic principles and bring science to bear against online disinformation.
item.dc:title: The disinformation sleuths: a key role for scientists in impending elections

item.title: Climate change pits clan against clan in drought-hit Somalia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03124-0

Amid battles for water and grazing land, an awareness of local power dynamics is key, says United Nations adviser Christophe Hodder.
item.dc:title: Climate change pits clan against clan in drought-hit Somalia
item.dc:creator: Shihab Jamal

item.title: Why rings of RNA could be the next blockbuster drug
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03058-7

The commercial success of RNA vaccines for COVID-19 has revved up interest in circular RNAs as the next generation of therapies.
item.dc:title: Why rings of RNA could be the next blockbuster drug
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin

item.title: How ‘retro’ meetings can enhance collaboration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03131-1

Allowing team members time to reflect, celebrate successes and learn from mistakes is a tried-and-tested way to foster continuous improvement.
item.dc:title: How ‘retro’ meetings can enhance collaboration
item.dc:creator: Akshay Swaminathan
Lathan Liou

item.title: Deep learning shows how global warming affects daily rainfall
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02803-2

An artificial-intelligence method called deep learning has been used to detect signals of human-induced climate change in daily precipitation data. The results indicate that global warming has increased day-to-day rainfall variability in tropical and mid-latitude regions over the past 40 years.
item.dc:title: Deep learning shows how global warming affects daily rainfall

item.title: Astronomers are worried by a satellite brighter than most stars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 04 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03132-0

Researchers determined the telecommunications satellite was periodically brighter than 99% of stars, and powerful X-rays have uncovered an ancient trilobite’s last meal.
item.dc:title: Astronomers are worried by a satellite brighter than most stars
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

Complex molecule synthesis by electrocatalytic decarboxylative cross-coupling

item.content:encoded:

The World Health Organization has recommended a shot called R21 to prevent the disease in children.

Are leprosy and Hansen’s disease identical?

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03038-x

Thunderstorms can increase the levels of water vapour in the atmosphere, at altitudes as high as 19 km.
item.dc:title: Summer storms launch water high into the stratosphere

item.title: Avoid patenting AI-generated inventions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03116-0

Avoid patenting AI-generated inventions

item.title: Seize the moment: researchers have a rare opportunity to make progress in protecting global biodiversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03103-5

A quiet revolution is taking place to incorporate the costs of biodiversity loss into economic planning. It needs researchers to be engaged.
item.dc:title: Seize the moment: researchers have a rare opportunity to make progress in protecting global biodiversity

item.title: Physicists who built ultrafast ‘attosecond’ lasers win Nobel Prize
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03047-w

Pierre Agostini, Ferenc Krausz and Anne L’Huillier receive award for ultra-short pulses of light, which have enabled the close study of electrons.
item.dc:title: Physicists who built ultrafast ‘attosecond’ lasers win Nobel Prize
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi
Katharine Sanderson

item.title: A ‘user’s manual for the female mammal’ — how women’s bodies evolved
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03059-6

The female perspective is often missed in evolutionary tales, but it is at the centre of what makes us human.
item.dc:title: A ‘user’s manual for the female mammal’ — how women’s bodies evolved
item.dc:creator: Josie Glausiusz

item.title: mRNA COVID vaccines saved lives and won a Nobel — what’s next for the technology?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03119-x

Nature talks to experts about how messenger RNA is transforming medicine.
item.dc:title: mRNA COVID vaccines saved lives and won a Nobel — what’s next for the technology?
item.dc:creator: Elie Dolgin
Heidi Ledford

item.title: AI beats human sleuth at finding problematic images in research papers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02920-y

An algorithm that takes just seconds to scan a paper for duplicated images racks up more suspicious images than a person.
item.dc:title: AI beats human sleuth at finding problematic images in research papers
item.dc:creator: Anil Oza

item.title: Daily briefing: Watch a hammerhead shark grow its hammer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 03 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03126-y

First study of hammerhead shark embryos shows how their heads develop their iconic shape. Plus, attoseconds physics wins Nobel Prize and a huge new satellite outshines nearly every star in the sky.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Watch a hammerhead shark grow its hammer
item.dc:creator: Katrina Krämer

item.title: How the littlest children stop SARS-CoV-2 in its tracks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03036-z

Compared with adults, babies have a weaker antibody response but better protection in their noses.
item.dc:title: How the littlest children stop SARS-CoV-2 in its tracks

item.title: How damaged are coral reefs? I dive to investigate climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03065-8

Marine biologist Long Ying studies how warmer, more-acidic oceans are affecting these ‘trees of the seas’.
item.dc:title: How damaged are coral reefs? I dive to investigate climate change
item.dc:creator: Nic Fleming

item.title: Interstellar shocks unveil the material around new stars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02982-y

Astronomers have obtained spectacular images of an interstellar jet launched from a newly forming star. Careful comparison with archival data offers a fresh take on the chemistry of the environment that surrounds it.
item.dc:title: Interstellar shocks unveil the material around new stars
item.dc:creator: Joel Green

item.title: Engaged in collaborative research? Try a touch of intellectual humility
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03063-w

Being open to the limitations of their knowledge can help researchers to foster interdisciplinary and cross-cultural collaborations.
item.dc:title: Engaged in collaborative research? Try a touch of intellectual humility
item.dc:creator: Jane Palmer

item.title: Daily briefing: Medicine Nobel Prize for mRNA research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03122-2

Biochemist Katalin Karikó and immunologist Drew Weissman have won the Nobel Prize for discoveries that enabled the development of mRNA COVID vaccines. Plus, the break-up of a supercontinent churned up rare pink diamonds and how a heart starts to beat.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Medicine Nobel Prize for mRNA research
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Huge new satellite outshines nearly every star in the sky
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03054-x

At times, the enormous telecommunications spacecraft is brighter than some of the most iconic stars visible from Earth.
item.dc:title: Huge new satellite outshines nearly every star in the sky
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall

item.title: How open-source software could finally get the world’s microscopes speaking the same language
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03064-9

A plethora of standards mean shareable and verifiable microscopy data often get lost in translation. Biologists are working on a solution.
item.dc:title: How open-source software could finally get the world’s microscopes speaking the same language
item.dc:creator: Michael Brooks

item.title: Why researchers should use human embryo models with caution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03062-x

Scientists should carefully consider whether embryo models based on human stem cells are essential to their work because of the associated practical and ethical challenges.
item.dc:title: Why researchers should use human embryo models with caution
item.dc:creator: Janet Rossant
Jianping Fu

item.title: Pioneers of mRNA COVID vaccines win medicine Nobel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 October 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03046-x

Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman laid the groundwork for immunizations that were rolled out during the pandemic at record-breaking speed.
item.dc:title: Pioneers of mRNA COVID vaccines win medicine Nobel
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway
Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Audio long read: These animals are racing towards extinction. A new home might be their last chance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02872-3

Researchers are testing a controversial strategy to relocate threatened animals whose habitats might not survive climate change.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: These animals are racing towards extinction. A new home might be their last chance
item.dc:creator: Clare Watson
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Genetic variant powers up immune cells that remember SARS-CoV-2
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03009-2

People with a specific variant had more active thymus glands, which produce immune cells that fight off infection.
item.dc:title: Genetic variant powers up immune cells that remember SARS-CoV-2

item.title: Daily briefing: ‘Elitist but essential’ — what our readers think about the Nobel Prizes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03110-6

More than half of respondents to our poll say the Nobels need to change. Plus, a US government shutdown would disrupt science and how researchers are tackling deepfakes.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: ‘Elitist but essential’ — what our readers think about the Nobel Prizes
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham
